head.title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Parties Find Common Ground On ETA

hedline.hl1: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Parties Find Common Ground On ETA

abstract.p: Prime Min Jose Luis Rodriguez Zapatero and Mariano Rajoy, leader of opposition party, hold their first meeting in Spain since Basque separatist group ETA called off cease-fire; they have been fiercely divided over Zapatero's earlier efforts to broker peace deal with group (S)

block.p: José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero, the Socialist prime minister, and Mariano Rajoy, the leader of the Popular Party, the conservative opposition, fiercely divided over Mr. Zapatero's earlier efforts to broker a peace deal with the violent Basque separatist group ETA, held their first meeting since the group called off a cease-fire last week. Officials from both sides offered an upbeat assessment of the meeting as a step toward healing the leaders' bitter rift and forging a united front against ETA.

José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero, the Socialist prime minister, and Mariano Rajoy, the leader of the Popular Party, the conservative opposition, fiercely divided over Mr. Zapatero's earlier efforts to broker a peace deal with the violent Basque separatist group ETA, held their first meeting since the group called off a cease-fire last week. Officials from both sides offered an upbeat assessment of the meeting as a step toward healing the leaders' bitter rift and forging a united front against ETA.
